metadata.titleEn: Vector dataset of glaciers and glacial lakes in the Boqu Basin in Central Himalaya (1976-2010)
metadata.description:
This is the 1976, 1991, 2000, and 2010 vector data set of glaciers and glacial lakes in the Boqu Basin in Central Himalaya based on Landsat satellite images.
The data source is from Landsat remote images.
1976: LM21510411975306AAA05, LM21510401976355AAA04
1991: LT41410401991334XXX02, LT41410411991334XXX02
2000: LE71410402000279SGS00, LE71400412000304SGS00, LE71410402000327EDC00, LE71410412000327EDC00
2010: LT51400412009288KHC00, LT51410402009295KHC00, LT51410412009311KHC00, LT51410402011237KHC00.
The boundaries of glaciers and glacial lakes are extracted manually from the various remote sensing images.
The extraction error of the boundaries of glaciers and glacial lakes is estimated to be 0.5 pixels.
Data file:
Glacial_1976: Glacier vector data in 1976
Glacial_1991: Glacier vector data in 1991
Glacial_2000: Glacier vector data in 2000
 Glacial_2010: Glacier vector data in 2010
Glacial_Lake_1976: Glacial lake vector data in 1976年
Glacial_Lake_1991: Glacial lake vector data in 1991
Glacial_Lake_2000: Glacial lake vector data in 2000
Glacial_Lake_2010: Glacial lake vector data in 2010
The glacial lake vector data fields include
Number, name, latitude and longitude, altitude, area, orientation, type of glacial lake, length, width, and distance from the glacier.

background: It is widely accepted that the majority of glaciers on the Tibetan Plateau are now retreating and thinning, although spatially systematic differences in glacier status are apparent and the exact mass loss remains controversial. Glacial retreat on the Tibetan Plateau not only affects water resources, runoff regimes, and hydrological processes in the region but also causes the formation and development of glacial lakes on/beneath/in front of mother glaciers. Such glacial lakes can be storehouses of fresh water, but they are also hazardous to humans and infrastructure as they can suddenly drain and cause devastating glacial lake outburst floods (GLOFs) downstream. A number of GLOFs have occurred on the Tibetan Plateau in the last several decades, and the majority have been concentrated in the Himalayas and the region south-east of the Tibetan Plateau. Previous GLOF events have demonstrated that glacial lakes are a potential threat to people living downstream because of their suddenness and the large land area that is affected. Rapid glacier retreat and intense rainfall in the monsoon season make this area one of the most GLOF-affected regions of the Tibetan Plateau. With global warming and glacial retreat, the frequency of GLOFs appears to have increased in recent years, and GLOF hazards in the Poiqu River basin are envisaged to increase significantly in the near future.
research objective: To address this need, this study provides an updated and complete outline of the glacial lakes in the Poiqu River basin using multi-temporal Landsat images. By analysing multiple phases of glacial lake inventories, we also investigate the distribution and development of glacial lakes in the Poiqu River basin from 1976 to 2010, with a special focus on the last decade. Our results are then linked to climate change and glacier fluctuations, to demonstrate how climate and glacier activity affect the status of glacial lakes.
challenges: Our method, therefore, only applies to the scenario of lake outburst as a consequence of impact waves from ice avalanches.
methods: Multi-temporal Landsat images from 1976 to 2010 were used in this study to inventory the glacial lakes in the Poiqu River basin and to study variations in the glacial lakes. Only the Landsat images acquired from late August to early December were chosen to avoid the high cloud obscuration during the monsoon season and ensure minimal snow coverage. For each phase of the glacial lake inventory, several images acquired on consecutive dates were used to ensure the reliable delineation of the glacial lakes’ boundaries. A 25-m digital elevation model (DEM) produced by the National Geomatics Center of China was also used in this study to derive the elevation of glacial lakes and to delineate watersheds for each of the lakes. Glacial lakes and their mother glaciers were manually identified and digitized on the basis of false-colour composite Landsat images. For the new inventory of glacial lakes in 2010, lakes larger than 0.01 km2 were digitized and catalogued according to specific attributes.
dataset: Multi-temporal Landsat images from 1976 to 2010 were used in this study to inventory the glacial lakes in the Poiqu River basin and to study variations in the glacial lakes. The Landsat images (L1T) were downloaded from the International Scientific and Technical Data Mirror Site, Computer Network Information Center, Chinese Academy of Sciences. A 25-m digital elevation model (DEM) produced by the National Geomatics Center of China was also used in this study to derive the elevation of glacial lakes and to delineate watersheds for each of the lakes.
findings: We found that lakes connected to glacial watersheds (glacier-fed lakes) significantly expanded (122.1%) from 1976 to 2010, whereas lakes not connected to glacial watersheds (non-glacier-fed lakes) remained stable (+2.8%) during the same period. The results presented in this study confirm the significant role of glacier retreat on the evolution of glacial lakes.

Definition.Question: What is meant by 'multi-temporal Landsat images' in the context of inventorying glacial lakes?
Definition.Answer: Multi-temporal Landsat images refer to satellite images from different time periods, specifically used to analyze changes in the glacial lakes over time. In this context, images from 1976 to 2010 are used to study variations in the glacial lakes in the Poiqu River basin, ensuring comprehensive temporal coverage and analysis of changes.

Definition.Question: What does 'manual identification and digitization of glacial lakes' involve in remote sensing?
Definition.Answer: Manual identification and digitization of glacial lakes involve the process of visually interpreting false-color composite Landsat images to identify the boundaries of glacial lakes and their mother glaciers. This is done by an analyst who digitizes these features, creating vector data that represent the lake boundaries and other relevant attributes.

Comparison.Question: How does the integration of a digital elevation model (DEM) enhance the inventory of glacial lakes compared to using Landsat imagery alone?
Comparison.Answer: The integration of a digital elevation model (DEM) enhances the inventory of glacial lakes by providing elevation data, which aids in delineating watersheds and understanding the topographical context of glacial lakes. This provides a more comprehensive analysis compared to using Landsat imagery alone, which primarily offers only surface-level data.

Interpretation.Question: What inferences can be drawn about glacier retreat patterns from the variation in glacial lake sizes over multiple decades?
Interpretation.Answer: The variation in glacial lake sizes, particularly the significant expansion of glacier-fed lakes, indicates that glacier retreat plays a crucial role in the evolution of glacial lakes, suggesting a strong correlation between glacial retreat patterns and the development of glacial lakes.

Interpretation.Question: How might the selection of Landsat images during specific months impact the accuracy and reliability of glacial lake boundary delineation?
Interpretation.Answer: Choosing Landsat images from late August to early December helps avoid high cloud cover and ensures minimal snow coverage, which enhances the accuracy and reliability of delineating glacial lake boundaries by reducing potential obstructions that could affect visibility and measurement precision.

Causal Antecedent.Question: Why is there a focus on using multi-temporal Landsat images specifically from late August to early December for glacial lake inventory in the Poiqu River basin?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Multi-temporal Landsat images from late August to early December are utilized to avoid high cloud cover prevalent during the monsoon season, which ensures minimal snow coverage and allows for clearer analysis of glacial lake boundaries.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What factors contribute to the significant expansion of glacier-fed lakes compared to non-glacier-fed lakes in the Poiqu River basin from 1976 to 2010?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The significant expansion of glacier-fed lakes is linked to the retreat of glaciers in the region, which affects the evolution of glacial lakes by increasing water input from melting glaciers, while non-glacier-fed lakes remain stable due to their lack of direct connection to glacial watersheds.

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the implications of using a 25-m digital elevation model (DEM) in conjunction with Landsat images for understanding the spatial distribution and elevation of glacial lakes?
Causal Consequence.Answer: The use of a 25-m DEM allows for accurate determination of the elevation and spatial distribution of glacial lakes, which is crucial for delineating watersheds. It enhances the understanding of lake-fed dynamics, but the resolution may limit the detection of smaller or more subtle topographic features.

Goal Orientation.Question: What is the rationale behind using a digital elevation model (DEM) in conjunction with Landsat images for studying glacial lakes?
Goal Orientation.Answer: A digital elevation model (DEM) is utilized alongside Landsat images to derive the elevation of glacial lakes and delineate watersheds, which is important for understanding the topographical context of the lakes and their potential impact on water resources and flood hazards.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What procedures are used to manually extract glacial and glacial lake boundaries from Landsat images in the context of this field?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: In this field, glacial and glacial lake boundaries are manually extracted from false-colour composite Landsat images. The process involves digitizing the boundaries of glaciers and glacial lakes directly from multi-temporal Landsat images, ensuring reliable delineation by using several images acquired on consecutive dates.

Enablement.Question: What remote sensing technologies and methodologies enable the accurate delineation of glacial and glacial lake boundaries over time?
Enablement.Answer: The use of multi-temporal Landsat images from 1976 to 2010 enabled the inventory and study of variations in glacial lakes in the Poiqu River basin. False-color composite Landsat images were utilized to manually identify and digitize glacial lakes and their mother glaciers. Images acquired from late August to early December were chosen to avoid high cloud obscuration and ensure minimal snow coverage.

Enablement.Question: How do digital elevation models (DEMs) contribute to the understanding and mapping of glacial lake characteristics in mountainous regions?
Enablement.Answer: A 25-m digital elevation model (DEM) produced by the National Geomatics Center of China was used to derive the elevation of glacial lakes and to delineate watersheds for each of the lakes. This helped in accurately mapping the characteristics of glacial lakes and understanding their development in correlation with elevation data.

Enablement.Question: What are the conditions and challenges involved in ensuring the reliability of glacial lake inventory data, particularly in monsoon-affected regions?
Enablement.Answer: To ensure the reliability of glacial lake inventory data, images were acquired on consecutive dates to ensure the reliable delineation of glacial lakes’ boundaries. Challenges included avoiding high cloud cover during the monsoon season, which was addressed by selecting images from late August to early December.

Expectation.Question: Why might manual extraction of glacial and glacial lake boundaries from remote sensing imagery be expected to introduce errors?
Expectation.Answer: Manual extraction of glacial and glacial lake boundaries is expected to introduce errors due to the subjective nature of human interpretation and the inherent limitations in accurately delineating features from imagery. The estimated extraction error is about 0.5 pixels, indicating the challenges in achieving precise boundary definitions.

Expectation.Question: What expectations might researchers have had regarding the stability of non-glacier-fed lakes compared to glacier-fed lakes from 1976 to 2010, and why?
Expectation.Answer: Researchers likely expected non-glacier-fed lakes to remain more stable compared to glacier-fed lakes due to the absence of direct glacial influence. The findings confirmed this expectation, showing that non-glacier-fed lakes remained stable (+2.8%), while glacier-fed lakes expanded significantly (122.1%) due to glacier retreat.

Expectation.Question: Why might the use of multi-temporal Landsat images be anticipated to enhance the inventory and analysis of glacial lakes over time?
Expectation.Answer: The use of multi-temporal Landsat images is anticipated to enhance the inventory and analysis of glacial lakes by providing a consistent and detailed temporal record that allows researchers to track changes and developments in glacial lakes over time. This approach helps in understanding patterns and trends related to climate change and glacier fluctuations.

Judgmental.Question: In your opinion, what are the benefits and limitations of using a 25-m digital elevation model (DEM) for analyzing glacial lakes and their watersheds?
Judgmental.Answer: Using a 25-m DEM offers the benefit of deriving precise elevation data and delineating watersheds, which is crucial for understanding the spatial dynamics of glacial lakes. However, the limitation may lie in its resolution, which might not capture finer topographic details that could impact hydrological modeling and hazard assessment.

Assertion.Question: I don't understand how data from different years can be consistently integrated into a dataset to track changes in glacial lakes over time.
Assertion.Answer: Multi-temporal Landsat images from different years, such as 1976, 1991, 2000, and 2010, are used to inventory and track variations in glacial lakes. These images are selected to ensure minimal cloud and snow coverage, and manual identification and digitization of glacial lakes and their mother glaciers are performed for consistent data integration.

Assertion.Question: I'm unsure about the challenges faced when extracting glacial lake boundaries from satellite images.
Assertion.Answer: One significant challenge is ensuring the reliable delineation of glacial lake boundaries, which is achieved by using several consecutive images from late August to early December to avoid high cloud obscuration and ensure minimal snow coverage. Manual extraction of boundaries can also introduce errors, estimated to be around 0.5 of a pixel.

Assertion.Question: I can't make sense of how glacier retreat impacts the development of glacial lakes in this region.
Assertion.Answer: The study found that glacier retreat plays a significant role in the evolution of glacial lakes. Lakes connected to glacial watersheds expanded significantly (122.1%) from 1976 to 2010, indicating that glacier retreat contributes to the development and expansion of these lakes.

Request/Directive.Question: Please explore the potential challenges faced in manually digitizing and identifying glacial lakes and glaciers using Landsat images.
Request/Directive.Answer: The manual digitization and identification of glacial lakes and their mother glaciers using false-colour composite Landsat images present challenges such as potential human error, the need for expert knowledge in interpreting remote sensing data, and the time-intensive nature of the process. Furthermore, the accuracy of boundary delineation is estimated to have an error of 0.5 pixels, which can affect the precision of the inventory.
